ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to listen to other people tell me what I should do with my project instead of encouraging me to further explore what I was already doing. Learned how to be given names of artists and say "Oh wow, I'll be sure to Google them!" and then never Google them

Learned how to analyze classmates' art more closely and critically. It was cool to see what other senior art majors were working on throughout the course of the year, and comment on their progress in the class critiques.

How to develop a self-initiated idea over a large span of time.
Thinking critically about the message you want to send.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Weaknesses: only one presentation a semester means you don't get many opportunities for feedback. The course shouldn't have an instructor. Just let the seniors run the show.

One strength of this course is that you get to connect with other senior art majors and see their projects, and have a discussion with each other about your work (helpful for troubleshooting, inspiration, constructive criticisms, etc.). It was also nice to have guest speakers come in occasionally.

One weakness is that you only get to work with your thesis advisor for one semester, in the spring. I think it would have been helpful to have an advisor in the fall, or for both semesters to offer more guidance, which could further lead to having more time to working on a formulated project idea.

I think the thesis advisors should be assigned before the spring. It would've been much more helpful to get started on our projects with advisors right after turning in our proposals in the fall. Personally, I got the bulk of my thesis work done over winter break which is an exception but I felt that other students would benefit from additional time with their advisor.
Pretty cool to see what other art majors are working on.

Strength: regular feedback and helpful professors
Weakness: timing. I didn't really like having class from 7-9pm. The feedback in the group discussions were also not very helpful given students' varying expertise and areas of study.Scheduling time with my advisor sometimes was difficult as well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual format was great, couldn't imagine how dreary this would've been in-person
It's really sad that this class was not in person but it was cool that we got speakers who didn't necessarily have to come to New Haven to share their insights and stories with us.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely not. If you can get out of it somehow, you should.
Yes, since it is required for art majors.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
